Condition

Investigation

Explanation

Hirschsprung’s disease

Rectal biopsy (C)

Gold standard test to confirm absence of ganglion cells in the colonic submucosa, leading to functional obstruction.

Posterior urethral valve

Micturating cystourethrogram (MCUG) (D)

Identifies posterior urethral obstruction due to congenital valves in male infants, causing urinary retention and hydronephrosis.

Choledochal cyst

MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) (A)

Best non-invasive imaging modality to visualize biliary tree anomalies, including cystic dilatation of the common bile duct.

Intussusception

On examination, a right–sided reniform ballotable mass was found. What investigations will you do? 1. CECT 2. PET-CT 3. 24 hour urinary VMA 4. FNAC
questions.explanation:
Investigation

Role in Diagnosis

Justification

CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT Scan)

First-line imaging for renal tumors

Determines tumor size, extent, local invasion, and vascular involvement (e.g., renal vein or IVC thrombus).

PET-CT (Positron Emission Tomography-CT)

Staging and metastasis detection

Helps assess lymph node involvement, lung, liver, and bone metastases. Also differentiates Wilms tumor vs. neuroblastoma.

24-hour urinary VMA (Vanillylmandelic Acid)

Differentiates Wilms tumor from Neuroblastoma

Neuroblastoma (adrenal origin) → elevated VMA levels; Wilms tumor does not produce catecholamines.

FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology)

Not recommended

Contraindicated in Wilms tumor due to risk of tumor spillage, which can lead to peritoneal dissemination. Core biopsy may be done in unclear cases.

Arrange the following in sequential order with regards to the steps of collection of samples for pap smear testing: Use posterior vaginal wall retractor Take the sample Make smear on a slide Fix the smear
questions.explanation:
Pap smear

Site
  • Transformation zone of the cervix, where the squamous epithelium (ectocervix) and columnar epithelium (endocervix) meet.
  • This is the most common site for cervical cancer to develop.

Instruments
  • Ayre spatula collects cells from the ectocervix
  • Cervical broom (also called a cytobrush) from the transition zone
  • Endocervical brush from endocervix

Procedure
  • Conventional Pap smear:
    • Step 1: Insert a posterior vaginal wall retractor (1) or speculum to expose the cervix for clear visibility and access.
    • Step 2: Use a small brush or spatula to collect cervical cells (2) by gently rotating the instrument.
    • Step 3: Smear the collected cells (3) onto a microscope slide, ensuring preservation of cell structure.
    • Step 4: Fix the smear (4) with a fixative to preserve the cells for subsequent lab analysis.
  • Liquid-based cytology: Cells are collected and then rinsed into a liquid fixative vial. This is considered more sensitive than the conventional Pap smear as it provides a more uniform distribution of cells.

Considerations
  • Sensitivity: A single Pap test has a sensitivity of 47-62% for detecting high-grade cervical lesions.
  • HPV co-testing: Combining the Pap smear with HPV DNA testing significantly improves screening accuracy.
  • Colposcopy: Colposcopy, with biopsy if indicated, is the gold standard for evaluating abnormal Pap results.

Indications
  • Cervical cancer screening: Routine screening for women aged 21-65 years, with the frequency and type of testing varying based on age and risk factors.
  • Evaluation of abnormal vaginal bleeding: While not a primary diagnostic tool, a Pap smear is performed as part of the workup, along with other tests.

Timing & Frequency
  • Age 21-29: Cytology (Pap smear) every 3 years.
  • Age 30-65: Co-testing (Pap smear + HPV testing) every 5 years.
  • >65: No further screening if they have had 3 consecutive negative cytology results or 2 consecutive negative co-test results and no history of high-grade precancerous lesions.
  • H/o of CIN 2 or higher: Annual screening for 20 years.
  • More frequent screening in HIV and Immunocompromised patients.

Contraindications

Avoided during menstruation. (Relative C/I)

questions.explanation:

Function

Thyroid Gland (Option A ruled out)

Other Tissues

questions.text: After a fracture in the femoral shaft, your consultant instructs you to apply tibia traction. Which of the following will you ask the nurse to provide? 1. Thomas splint 2. K-wire 3. Steinmann pin 4. Denham's pin 5. Bohler's stirrup 6. Bohler Braun splint
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Orthopaedic Instruments - Surgical Holdings
  • ↳ Proximal femoral nail fixation | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org

Instrument

Images

Proximal Femur Nail (PFN)

  • The Proximal Femoral Nail (PFN) is used for closed intramedullary fixation of proximal femoral fractures.
  • It features two proximal openings for a femoral neck lag screw and an anti-rotation screw.
  • Indications include peritrochanteric, intertrochanteric, and subtrochanteric fractures.
  • It is contraindicated for medial femoral neck fractures.

Kuntscher Nail

  • Used for internal fixation of femoral fractures.
  • The nail is a hollow tube with a cloverleaf shape for rotational stability.
  • Fixation is based on three-point fixation: at both ends and the isthmus.
  • Each end has an "eye" for the extractor hook during removal.
  • Nail size is determined by measuring from the greater trochanter to the lateral knee joint line and subtracting 2 cm.
  • About 2 cm of the nail is left protruding at the trochanter for removal, usually 2 years post-operation.

Kirschner wire (K wire)

  • Thin, straight steel wire with a diameter of 1 to 3 mm.
  • Uses include:
    • Internal fixation of small bones.
    • Tension band wiring in patella
    • Applying traction (e.g., through the olecranon).
    • Fixing fractures in children.
    • Used in Ilizarov’s fixation system.

Steinmann Pin

  • Stout, straight steel rod with a diameter of 3 to 6 mm.
  • Primarily used for skeletal traction.
  • Common sites for insertion include the upper end of the tibia, the supracondylar region of the femur, and the calcaneum.

Bohler’s Stirrup

  • A device used for holding a Steinmann pin and applying traction.
  • Side screws secure the pin in place.
  • Allows for changing the direction of traction without moving the pin inside the bone.
  • Helps avoid loosening of the pin during traction adjustments.

Thomas Splint:

  • Primarily for the stabilization and immobilization of fractures in the femur or tibia.
  • It consists of a metal frame that supports the limb, preventing movement and reducing the risk of further injury.

Steinmann Pin:

  • It is a large, stainless steel pin used for internal fixation of fractures or to stabilize bones during surgery.
  • Typically inserted percutaneously (through the skin) or during surgery and is used to hold bones in place for proper healing.

Denham's Pin:

  • It is used for joint stabilization, often in the hip joint.
  • It is inserted into the bone and can be used for traction or temporary stabilization while healing.

Bohler-Braun Splint:

  • Splint used for the immobilization of fractures, especially in the thigh and leg.
  • It is a two-piece splint made of metal and is commonly used for fractures of the femur and tibia.

  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb

questions.explanation:
Correct answer A) Transurethral resection of the tumour

Tumor Stage

Tis (Carcinoma in situ)

TURBT (Transurethral Resection of Bladder Tumor)

  • May be used for initial diagnosis and tumor resection if not already performed

Intravesical BCG

  • Induction: Weekly for 6 weeks
  • Maintenance: Weekly for 3 weeks at months 3, 6, 12, 18, 24, 30, and 36

Continue BCG Maintenance Therapy

  • Up to 3 years

Ta (Non-muscle invasive)

TURBT

  • Complete resection of tumor

Low-risk:

  • Single Instillation (SI) of Intravesical Chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine, mitomycin)
  • SI within 24 hours of TURBT
  • Alternative: Continuous saline bladder irrigation

Intermediate-risk:

  • Intravesical Chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine)
  • Induction: 6 weekly courses
  • Maintenance: Up to 1 year

T1 (Muscle invasive)

TURBT- For initial diagnosis and tumor debulking

High-risk:

  • Intravesical BCG
  • Induction: Weekly for 6 weeks
  • Maintenance: Up to 3 years

Consider Cystectomy

  • If BCG is not tolerated or ineffective- Alternative: Trimodality therapy (TURBT + Chemoradiation)

T2 (Muscle invasive)

TURBT- May be used for tumor resection and staging

Initial Treatment:

  • Consider Cystectomy
  • Alternatively, Trimodality therapy (TURBT + Chemoradiation)

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Depending on response and tumor characteristics

T3 (Advanced muscle invasive)

Initial Treatment:

  • Cystectomy with possible neoadjuvant chemotherapy

TURBT - Often not performed if cystectomy is planned

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Based on pathology and staging
  • Neoadjuvant therapy may continue

T4 (Locally advanced)

Initial Treatment:

  • Cystectomy
  • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy, if not yet administered

TURBT- Typically avoided if cystectomy and neoadjuvant therapy are planned

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Additional chemotherapy or radiation based on residual disease and staging

Which of the following statements are true? 1. Due to increasing mammography there occurs over diagnosis of breast carcinoma 2. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination 3. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection 4. Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear
questions.explanation:
Correct answer D) 1, 3, 4

Statement

True/False

Explanation

1. Due to increasing mammography, there occurs overdiagnosis of breast carcinoma.

True

Widespread mammography detects early-stage cancers and indolent tumors, leading to overdiagnosis and possibly unnecessary treatments.

2. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination (DRE).

False

DRE alone is NOT an effective screening test for colon cancer. Preferred tests are colonoscopy, fecal occult blood test (FOBT), and fecal immunochemical test (FIT).

3. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection.

True

Oral cancer screening involves visual examination and palpation of the oral mucosa, especially in high-risk individuals (e.g., smokers, betel nut chewers).

4. Cervical cancer screening is done by a Pap smear.

True

Pap smear (Papanicolaou test) detects cervical dysplasia and early-stage cancer, making it the gold standard screening test. HPV testing is also recommended in some guidelines.

questions.text: Which of the following structures are incised by a surgeon during an appendectomy performed initially with a gridiron incision? 1. External oblique 2. Internal oblique 3. Transversus abdominis 4. Rectus abdominis
questions.explanation:
McBurney's incision
  • Centered on McBurney's point, perpendicular to the umbilical ASIS line
  • Junction of lateral 1/3 from umbilicus & medial 2/3 from ASIS
  • McBurney's point corresponds to the base of the appendix
  • Muscle splitting incision
  • Aka Grid iron incision / McArthur incision

Lanz incision

Placed transversely 2 cm below the umbilicus on the line joining the midpoint of the clavicle to the midpoint of the inguinal ligament
  • Muscle splitting incision
  • Cosmetically better incision
  • Aka Modified McBurney's incision / Rocky Davis incision / Bikini incision (good cosmetic appearance)

Rutherford-Morrison incision
  • Extension of McBurney's incision for retrocecal appendicitis
  • Upward & laterally by cutting conjoint tendon
  • Muscle cutting incision
  • Preferred for retrocecal appendix

questions.text: What is the dose of carbetocin used in the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.explanation:
Drug/Treatment

Dosage/Administration

Key Notes

Oxytocin (IV)

10-20 units in drip
  • Drug of choice for uterine atony
  • Never give undiluted bolus dose (causes hypotension and arrhythmias)
  • Oxytocin overdose causes water intoxication

Carbetocin

100 mcg in 1 ml IV over 1 min
  • Synthetic analogue of oxytocin, more sustained release
  • Onset: 2 mins, lasts 1 hour (compared to oxytocin's onset of 5 mins and lasts 20 mins)
  • Equivalent to 16 hrs of oxytocin drip

Methylergometrine

0.2 mg IV (also IM, IV acts faster)
  • Peak action in 90 seconds
  • Can be given IM, but IV acts faster

Misoprostol (PGE1)

1000 μg per rectum or 200-400 μg sublingually
  • Prostaglandin used for postpartum hemorrhage
  • Effective for uterine contraction

Carboprost (PGFα)

250 μg IM only
  • Never given IV (causes sudden hypertension)
  • Can be administered intra-myometrial
  • Used when other drugs are ineffective

Tranexamic Acid

1 gm IV
  • Anti-fibrinolytic agent
  • Helps prevent bleeding by inhibiting fibrinolysis

Fibrinogen

Maintain >100 mg/dl
  • For maintaining fibrinogen levels
  • Can be administered as 10 units of cryoprecipitate or 1 litre of fresh frozen plasma (FFP)

options.label: C
options.text: Moving pH away from isoelectric pH

questions.correct_answer: C. Moving pH away from isoelectric pH
questions.explanation:
Method

Mechanism of precipitation

1. Heat

2. Strong mineral acids
  • Cause precipitation by denaturation

3. Heavy metal salts in alkaline medium

In alkaline medium

  • Proteins are negatively are positively charged
  • So, Neutralization of charges occur which leads to precipitation known as positive ion precipitation

4. Alkaloidal reagents (Trichloroacetic acid, phosphotungstic acid, sulfosalicylic acid)
  • Alkaloidal reagents are negatively charged
  • In acidic medium , protein are positively charged
  • So, Neutrialization of charges occur & leads to negative ion precipitation

5. Organic solvents e.g. alcohol & acetone

6. Neutral salts e.g. ammonium sulfate
  • Both cause precipitation by dehydration of proteins

questions.text: What is the frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring?
questions.explanation:
Heading

Details

Definition

A monitor that assesses the effect of neuromuscular blockers on the neuromuscular junction.

What it monitors
  • Onset of blockade
  • Intensity of blockade
  • Reversal from blockade
  • Involves two electrodes attached along the course of the ulnar nerve.

Procedure
  • Stimulate the ulnar nerve.
  • Observe the response in the adductor pollicis muscle.
  • Assess contraction to determine the degree of neuromuscular junction blockade.

Common site

Ulnar nerve

Principle

Supramaximal electrical stimulus is given to an accessible peripheral nerve (e.g., ulnar nerve), and the response is observed in the corresponding muscle group.

Types of Stimulus Given
  • Single twitch
  • Train of four (TOF): Most common; 4 stimuli delivered at 2 Hz
  • Tetanic stimulus: Continuous stimulus at 50 Hz
  • Double burst stimulation

Post-Tetanic count
  • Counting of responses to single twitch stimulation after tetanic stimulation at 50 Hz or 100 Hz for 5 seconds.
  • Indicates profound neuromuscular blockade if post-tetanic count is less than 5.

Stimulation Pattern

Mechanism

Interpretation

Clinical Implication and Limitation

Single-Twitch Stimulation

Single electrical stimulus applied at a frequency of 0.1 Hz to 1 Hz.
  • Requires comparison to pre-NMBA administration value.
  • Muscle response to the stimulus reflects neuromuscular block onset; changes in twitch height help assess blockade.
  • Used to evaluate onset of neuromuscular block.
  • Limited utility as a standalone test.

Train-of-Four (TOF) Stimulation


 

Four supramaximal stimuli delivered at 0.5-second intervals (2 Hz).
  • Fade between responses indicates degree of block.
  • TOF count assesses onset.
  • TOF ratio measures recovery.
  • Fade suggests nondepolarizing block.
  • Most common pattern for intraoperative monitoring.
  • Cannot measure deep block or phase I block.

Double-Burst Stimulation (DBS)


 

Two bursts of 50-Hz stimulation with a 750-ms interval.
  • Fade between the two bursts indicates block.
  • Fade between bursts correlates with TOF ratio.
  • DBS is more sensitive for detecting fade.

Better tactile detection of residual block than TOF but cannot reliably assess recovery at higher TOF ratios.

Tetanic Stimulation

High-frequency stimulation (50-100 Hz for 5 seconds) causing sustained muscle contraction.

Fade indicates nondepolarizing block; sustained response suggests normal transmission or depolarizing block.
  • Painful and limited use in practice.
  • May cause lasting muscle antagonism, affecting recovery assessment.

Post Tetanic Count (PTC) Stimulation


 

Tetanic stimulation (50 Hz for 5 seconds) followed by single twitches at 1 Hz after 3 seconds.

Counts discernible twitches after tetanic stimulation; assesses deep block not detectable by TOF.
  • Used for monitoring deep neuromuscular blockade.
  • Requires 6-minute intervals, limiting continuous use.

questions.text: How long should elective surgery be deferred for a patient who had a cough and fever, after he has recovered from COVID-19, and has not required any hospitalization?
questions.explanation:
Time since COVID-19 infection

Recommendation

Less than 2 Weeks

Elective surgeries should not occur within two weeks of a COVID-19 infection, allowing anesthesiologists and surgeons to assess the severity of the patient's symptoms and reduce unnecessary risk of transmitting the infection to healthcare professionals.

2 to 7 Weeks

Between two and seven weeks after the patient's COVID-19 infection, anesthesiologists and surgeons should conduct a risk assessment, considering factors such as age, comorbidities, severity of the infection, and surgical risk. If the patient and surgery are determined to be low risk, the procedure may be scheduled during this period after thorough discussion and shared decision-making with the patient.

More than 7 Weeks

Delay of the surgery beyond seven weeks should be considered if the patient continues to have COVID-19 symptoms or other health concerns that may increase the risk of proceeding with surgery.

A 50-year-old man suddenly developed right-sided weakness and aphasia within 2 hours. His BP recorded was 160/110mmHg and NCCT was clear. What is the next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: CT angiography to look for large vessel occlusion

questions.correct_answer: A. CT angiography to look for large vessel occlusion
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - CT angiography to look for large vessel occlusion:

Workup for stroke

Initial Assessment and Stabilization
  • Upon arrival, ensure the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) are stable.
  • Blood glucose levels should be checked quickly to address hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia.

Determining Stroke Type: Imaging is Key
  • A non-contrast CT scan is the primary imaging modality for differentiating between ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes.
  • Clinical features may suggest stroke type, but imaging is essential for confirmation as no clinical finding can definitively differentiate between the two.

Further Investigations: Uncovering the Cause
  • Detailed History and Physical Exam: Consider risk factors (hypertension, diabetes, smoking, atrial fibrillation, etc.) and perform a neurological exam to localize the affected brain area.
  • Laboratory Tests: Perform CBC, electrolytes, renal function, blood glucose, lipid profile, coagulation studies, ESR, and ECG (to detect arrhythmias and signs of recent MI).

Visualizing the Cerebral Vasculature: Imaging Techniques
  • CT Angiography (CTA): Assesses cerebral vasculature and identifies blockages/stenosis, but is performed after non-contrast CT has ruled out hemorrhage (not for stroke type differentiation).
  • CT Perfusion Imaging: Assesses blood flow, identifying reduced perfusion and ischemic penumbra.
  • MRI: Provides more detail but takes longer than CT and is not as widely available, thus not the first imaging choice for acute stroke evaluation. (Option B)
  • MRA: Offers detailed images of blood vessels, similar to CTA.
  • Cerebral Angiography: Gold standard for vessel evaluation, used when other techniques are inconclusive or before endovascular intervention.
  • Ultrasound Techniques: Carotid Duplex Ultrasonography assesses carotid stenosis but is not a first-line acute imaging modality; Transcranial Doppler (TCD) measures blood flow velocity in intracranial arteries.

Tailoring Investigations Based on Stroke Type
  • Ischemic Stroke: Focuses on identifying the source of the blockage (cardioembolic, artery-to-artery embolic, small vessel disease).
  • Hemorrhagic Stroke: Investigations focus on identifying causes of bleeding (e.g., hypertension, aneurysm, vascular malformation).

  • ↳ Osmotic demyelination syndrome:
  • ↳ Severe hyponatremia: Can lead to seizures, coma, and death in acute cases.
  • ↳ Severe hyponatremia:

Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH)

Definition

Excessive ADH release leading to impaired water excretion and hyponatremia with euvolemia or hypervolemia. (Option D)

Etiology
  • CNS disturbances: Stroke, infection, subarachnoid hemorrhage, etc.
  • Malignancies: Small cell lung cancer (most common), other cancers.
  • Drugs: Carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, SSRIs, "Ecstasy", NSAIDs, etc.
  • Surgery: Pain-induced ADH hypersecretion.
  • Pulmonary diseases: Pneumonia (Option A ruled out), respiratory failure, etc.
  • Hormone deficiency: Hypopituitarism, hypothyroidism.
  • HIV: Associated with infections.
  • Hereditary SIADH: V2 receptor mutation.

Pathophysiology
  • ADH function: Regulates water balance by controlling plasma osmolality; excess ADH causes water retention, leading to hyponatremia.
  • Volume regulation: In hypovolemia, ADH release is driven by volume receptors, worsening hyponatremia.

Clinical Presentation
  • Acute hyponatremia: Nausea, vomiting, headache, seizures, coma.
  • Chronic hyponatremia: Nonspecific symptoms (nausea, confusion, falls in elderly).

Diagnosis

Schwartz and Bartter Criteria:

  • Serum sodium <135 mEq/L (Option B)
  • Serum osmolality <275 mOsm/kg
  • Urine sodium >40 mEq/L
  • Urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg (Option C)
  • The absence of clinical evidence of volume depletion (like normal skin turgor, blood pressure within the reference range)
  • The absence of hyponatremia due to other causes (like adrenal insufficiency, hypothyroidism, cardiac failure, pituitary insufficiency, renal disease with salt wastage, hepatic disease, drugs that impair renal water excretion.)

Tests:

  • Renal function, serum osmolality, cortisol levels, thyroid tests, imaging for underlying causes.

Management
  • Fluid restriction: For mild to moderate symptoms.
  • Hypertonic saline (3%): For severe hyponatremia, with careful correction rate (<8 mEq/L in 24 hrs).
  • Medications:
    • Vasopressin receptor antagonists (Conivaptan, Tolvaptan)
    • Other: Loop diuretics, salt tablets, demeclocycline, lithium.

Complications
  • Osmotic demyelination syndrome: Risk from rapid sodium correction.
  • Severe hyponatremia: Can lead to seizures, coma, and death in acute cases.

A man with a fever of unknown origin has a job that requires traveling around the world. The histology of the bone marrow is shown below. Which of the following investigations would be the most appropriate in this case?
questions.explanation:
Microscopy

Demonstration of amastigotes in smears of tissue aspirates is the gold standard for diagnosis of kala-azar / VL

Materials collected:

1. Peripheral blood smear: Peripheral blood contains the amastigotes present inside circulating monocytes. It is best to examine buffy coat smear, Buffy coat smears show a diurnal periodicity, more smears being positive when collected during the day than at night.

Blood smear test showing macrophages with amastigotes and extracellular Leishmania parasites (white arrows).

2. Bone marrow aspirate: Generally, the sternal marrow is aspirated by puncturing the sternum at the level of the 2nd or 3rd intercostal space, using a sternal puncture needle. Bone marrow samples can also be obtained by puncturing the Iliac crest.

Bone marrow aspirate showed Leishmania donovani bodies (LD bodies) in macrophages characterized by a kinetoplast and characteristic double dot appearance (Fig. A and B).

3. Splenic aspirate (most sensitive): Splenic aspirates are richer in parasites and, therefore, are more valuable for diagnosis. Splenic aspiration is contraindicated in patients with prolonged prothrombin time or if platelet count is less than 40,000/mm³

4. Lymph node aspirate: It is not useful in the diagnosis of Indian kala-azar

Culture

Media: NNN (Novy, MacNeal and Nicolle).

Serodiagnosis
  1. Detection of antigen: ELISA and PCR
  2. Detection of antibody:
    • rk39 test (Option A): A specific rapid immunochromatographic test (ICT) method for antibodies using a recombinant leishmanial antigen rk 39. The sensitivity of the test is 98% and specificity is 90%.
    • Complement fixation test
    • Indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFAT)
    • Counter immunoelectrophoresis (CIEP)
    • ELISA and DOT-ELISA
    • Direct agglutination test (DAT)

Non-specific serum tests
  1. Napier aldehyde test
  2. Chopra's antimony test

Skin test

  • Leishmanin skin test- Montenegro test: Delayed hypersensitivity test.
  • Positive result is indicated by induration and erythema of 5 mm or more after 48-72 hours.
  • Positive result indicates prior exposure to the leishmanial parasites. In active kala-azar, this test is negative and becomes positive usually 6-8 weeks after cure from the disease.

Image obtained after 48 hours after injection

Complete blood count
  • It shows normocytic normochromic anemia and thrombocytopenia.
  • Leukocyte count reveals leukopenia.
  • The ratio of leukocyte to erythrocyte is greatly altered and may be about 1:200 to 1:100 (normal 1:750).
  • The serum shows hypergammaglobulinemia and a reversal of the albumin: globulin (A: G) ratio.
  • Liver function tests show mild elevations of liver enzymes.
  • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is elevated.

questions.explanation:
Transamination Process
  • Transfer of an α-amino group from an amino acid to one keto acid, producing a new α-keto acid and a new amino acid.
  • The first step is the catabolism of most amino acids.
  • All amino acids, except Proline, hydroxyproline, threonine, and lysine, participate in transamination.

Biological Importance

Amino Acid Interconversion: Maintains balance of non-essential amino acids by transferring amino groups to synthesise needed amino acids.

Ammonia Disposal: Detoxifies ammonia by funnelling amino groups into glutamate, which is deaminated in the liver for excretion.
Glutamate's Role

α-Ketoglutarate: Acts as an acceptor of amino groups from most amino acids, converting to glutamate.
Transamination occurs in the cytoplasm; the amino group is transported to the liver as glutamate.

Oxidative Deamination: Glutamate undergoes rapid oxidative deamination in the mitochondria to form α-ketoglutarate, which can accept another amino group.
Enzymes

Aminotransferases (Transaminases): Catalyse the transfer of amino groups between carbon skeletons. They are not coenzymes.

Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT): Transfers amino group from alanine to α-ketoglutarate, forming pyruvate and glutamate.

Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST): Transfers amino groups from glutamate to oxaloacetate, forming aspartate used in the urea cycle.
Coenzyme Pyridoxal Phosphate (PLP): Required by all aminotransferases, derived from vitamin B6.
Reversibility Transamination reactions are reversible, with equilibrium constants near 1.

Activators of GDH

Inhibitors of GDH

NAD

ATP

ADP

GTP

GDP

NADH

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient with heart failure is scheduled for a heart transplant. His renal function test is deranged, and haemoglobin is 6gm%. The physician ordered 2 units of whole blood. Four hours after transfusion, he developed severe respiratory distress. On examination, he is hypoxemic, has tachycardia and his mean arterial pressure is elevated. Which of the following are the best investigations for the above scenario? Chest X-ray Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) level Absolute neutrophil count Leucocyte antibodies Platelets
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - 1 and 2

Features

  • Occur after transfusion of red blood cells or plasma products in 1% to 8.9% of transfusions.
  • Has become the leading cause of transfusion-related deaths

Causes/Risk Factors

  • Older age
  • Renal failure
  • Preexisting fluid overload
  • Cardiac dysfunction
  • Administration of a large volume of blood components
  • Excessive transfusion rate beyond the patient's hemodynamic tolerance.

Diagnosis

  • Hypoxia, dyspnea
  • Tachycardia
  • Systolic hypertension
  • Left heart failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Increased central venous pressure
  • Elevated brain natriuretic peptide (BNP)
  • Chest X-ray: Bilateral alveolar infiltrates

Prevention

  • Identify at-risk patients.
  • Close monitoring and slow transfusion rates, 1 RBC concentrate over 3-4 hours.
  • Diuretics for hemodynamically stable patients with a history of TACO.

Treatment

  • Stopping the transfusion
  • Administering oxygen
  • Diuretics

questions.text: A young man presented with hearing loss and tinnitus. Histology image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Origin: Schwann cells; Site: CP angle

Pathology
  • Antoni A areas: These areas are composed of tightly packed spindle-shaped cells with elongated nuclei. The cells are arranged in palisades or whorls, forming Verocay bodies. The cells in Antoni A areas exhibit nuclear hyperchromasia (increased staining intensity) and cellular cohesion.
  • Antoni B areas: These areas are less cellular and show a looser arrangement of cells with a myxoid or microcystic appearance. The cells in Antoni B areas may have more irregular nuclei and a less distinct cytoplasmic organization compared to Antoni A areas.

Clinical presentation
  • 40-60 years, Males = Females
  • Unilateral sensorineural hearing loss associated with tinnitus

Radiology
  • Investigation of choice/Gold standard: MRI with Gadolinium contrast - ice cream cone appearance seen on CP angle.
  • Other investigations:
    • CT (with/without contrast): done when MRI is not feasible
    • Vertebral Angiography: though helps in localizing the tumor, it is not the investigation of choice.

Association
  • Neurofibromatosis type-2 (NF-2): Presents with bilateral Schwannomas and other tumors like Meningioma, ependymoma may also be associated.

Differential diagnoses

CP angle meningioma:

  • MRI: Dural tail sign seen

Glomus tumor: (Glomus jugulare)

  • Arises from the dome of Jugular bulb within the jugular fossa.
  • CT: Phelp sign (Bony erosion seen between carotid canal and jugular fossa)

questions.text: Asherman syndrome is most commonly associated with
Identify the instrument given below.

What is the probable diagnosis for a person who has facial swelling and orbital edema on the left side of their face after a minor trauma involving a piece of wood 20 days ago? The CT scan showed no abnormalities in the sinuses but revealed subcutaneous nodules. Microscopic examination of tissue sections showed positivity for PAS stain and Grocott's methenamine silver stain.
questions.explanation:
Mucormycosis

Description

A severe fungal infection primarily affects the nose and sinuses but can quickly spread to the orbit, cribriform plate, meninges, and brain. The fungus invades arteries, causing endothelial damage, thrombosis, and rapid tissue destruction.

Characteristic Findings

Black necrotic material in the nasal cavity, eroding the nasal septum, hard palate, and turbinates. Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast enhanced MRI.

Risk Factors
  • Uncontrolled diabetes, especially with ketoacidosis
  • Prolonged steroid use (common in COVID-19 treatment)
  • Conditions causing immunosuppression: Neutropenia, HIV/AIDS, chemotherapy, organ transplants, and kidney issues.

Diagnosis
  • Endoscopy: Shows pale mucosa early, progressing to black crusts and sloughing.
  • Biopsy: Multiple sites should be sampled for fungal identification; potassium hydroxide preparation is the gold standard for confirming invasive features.

Imaging
  • CT: Detects bony destruction and initial assessment of sinus involvement.
  • CECT: CECT provides better delineation of soft tissue structures, allowing for clearer identification of mucosal thickening, sinus opacification, and bony destruction.
  • MRI: Evaluates soft tissue invasion, assesses the extent of extra-sinus disease, and identifies complications, especially in the orbit and brain.

Treatment

Antifungal Therapy:

  • Amphotericin B: 0.6 to 1 mg/kg/day IV or liposomal Amphotericin B: 5 mg/kg/day.
  • Posaconazole: 300 mg twice daily orally on the first day, then 300 mg once daily.

Surgical Intervention:

  • Endoscopic debridement of necrotic tissues.
  • Severe cases: Total/Partial maxillectomy or orbital exenteration may be required.

questions.text: For which procedure is the following set of instruments used?
questions.explanation:
Pap smear

Site
  • Transformation zone of the cervix, where the squamous epithelium (ectocervix) and columnar epithelium (endocervix) meet.
  • This is the most common site for cervical cancer to develop.

Instruments
  • Ayre spatula collects cells from the ectocervix
  • Cervical broom (also called a cytobrush) from transition zone
  • Endocervical brush from endocervix

Procedure
  • Conventional Pap smear:
    • Step 1: Insert a posterior vaginal wall retractor or speculum to expose the cervix for clear visibility and access.
    • Step 2: Use a small brush or spatula to collect cervical cells by gently rotating the instrument.
    • Step 3: Smear the collected cells onto a microscope slide, ensuring preservation of cell structure.
    • Step 4: Fix the smear with a fixative to preserve the cells for subsequent lab analysis.
  • Liquid-based cytology: Cells are collected and then rinsed into a liquid fixative vial. This is considered more sensitive than the conventional Pap smear as it provides a more uniform distribution of cells.

Considerations
  • Sensitivity: A single Pap test has a sensitivity of 47-62% for detecting high-grade cervical lesions.
  • HPV co-testing: Combining the Pap smear with HPV DNA testing significantly improves screening accuracy.
  • Colposcopy: Colposcopy, with biopsy if indicated, is the gold standard for evaluating abnormal Pap results.

Indications
  • Cervical cancer screening: Routine screening for women aged 21-65 years, with the frequency and type of testing varying based on age and risk factors.
  • Evaluation of abnormal vaginal bleeding: While not a primary diagnostic tool, a Pap smear is performed as part of the workup, along with other tests.

Timing & Frequency
  • Age 21-29: Cytology (Pap smear) every 3 years.
  • Age 30-65: Co-testing (Pap smear + HPV testing) every 5 years.
  • >65: No further screening if they have had 3 consecutive negative cytology results or 2 consecutive negative co-test results and no history of high-grade precancerous lesions.
  • H/o of CIN 2 or higher: Annual screening for 20 years.
  • More frequent screening in HIV and Immunocompromised patients.

Contraindications

Avoided during menstruation. (Relative C/I)

V1 (Pre-foraminal)

Arises from subclavian artery, enters C6 transverse foramen.

V2 (Foraminal)

Ascends through transverse foramina (C6 to C1).

V3 (Extracranial/Suboccipital)

Enters the skull via foramen magnum, joins contralateral vertebral artery to form basilar artery.

A 65-year-old patient presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and occasional blood-stained nasal discharge. His CT and endoscopy findings are shown in the below image. What could be the underlying cause?
questions.explanation:
Inverted Papilloma

Origin

Arises from the non-olfactory mucosa (Schneiderian membrane) of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses

Other Names

Transitional cell papilloma, Ringertz tumor, Schneiderian papilloma

Most Common Site

Lateral wall of the nose, particularly in the middle meatus.

Growth Pattern

Inward growth of hyperplastic tissue toward the stroma.

Association with HPV

Linked to Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection (particularly types 6 and 11)

Risk of Malignancy

Associated with squamous cell carcinoma in 10-15% of cases.

Symptoms

Unilateral nasal obstruction, epistaxis (nosebleeds), and possible recurrent sinus infections.

Diagnosis

Endoscopic examination and biopsy for histopathological confirmation.

Treatment

Primary treatment is complete endoscopic surgical excision to minimize the risk of recurrence and malignant transformation.

questions.text: Nivolumab is used as a checkpoint inhibitor in which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Hodgkin’s lymphoma

Nivolumab
  • Nivolumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) receptor on T cells.

MOA
  • PD-1 is a checkpoint protein that is expressed on the surface of T cells
  • It helps to regulate the immune response by inhibiting T-cell activation and proliferation.
  • It has two ligands, PD-L1 and PD-L2, and when PD-1 binds to these ligands, it sends a signal to the T cell to "turn off" and stop attacking the cancer cell.
  • By blocking the PD-1 checkpoint, nivolumab enhances the anti-tumour activity of T cells and promotes an immune response against cancer cells.

 

  • It is different from traditional chemotherapy and radiation therapy, and it is considered a type of immunotherapy that harnesses the immune system to fight cancer.

Uses

  • Replasped classical Hodgkin’s lymphoma
  • Advanced melanoma
  • Advanced non-small cell lung cancer (that was previously treated)
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Head and neck cancer

Side effects

  • Rash
  • Fatigue, muscle pain
  • Reduced appetite
  • Constipation
  • Pneumonitis
  • Colitis
  • Nephritis
  • Hepatitis

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective drug in smoking cessation?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - V

 

Mechanism of Action

Effect on Smoking Cessation

First-Line Drugs

Bupropion

Blocks reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine in the brain

Reduces nicotine withdrawal symptoms and cravings

Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT)

Provides controlled nicotine dose (patches, gum, lozenges, inhalers). Never given orally, sublingual due to its fast absorption

Alleviates withdrawal symptoms and cravings, gradually reducing nicotine dependence

Varenicline

Binds to nicotine receptors in the brain, partially stimulating them.

Most effective drug.

Reduces cravings and pleasurable effects of smoking.

Used in tobacco chewing.
S/E: Depression (suicides)

All first-line drugs are C/I in seizures and heart diseases (MI, angina, hypertension)

Second-Line Drugs

Clonidine
 

Alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, reduces sympathetic nervous system activity
  • Alleviates withdrawal symptoms such as anxiety, irritability, and restlessness.
  • Safe in patients with heart disease/seizure.

Nortriptyline

 

Tricyclic antidepressant, affecting norepinephrine and serotonin levels
  • Reduces withdrawal symptoms and cravings

Topiramate

 

Blocks glutamate receptors and facilitates GABA neurotransmission
  • Potentially facilitates smoking cessation

Mecamylamine

Blocks nicotine receptors in the brain
  • Reduces the rewarding effects of nicotine, making smoking less appealing.
  • Used in nicotine poisoning.

questions.text: Category A, B, C, D, and X in drug classification are indicative of which of the following?

options.label: C
options.text: Cost ratio from cheap to expensive

options.label: D
options.text: As per the safety or therapeutic index

questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Safety in pregnancy:

 

Category A

Adequate and well-controlled studies have failed to demonstrate a risk to the fetus in the first trimester of pregnancy, and there is no evidence of risk in later trimesters.

Examples - Doxylamine, Folate and Levothyroxine

Category B

Animal reproduction studies have failed to demonstrate a risk to the fetus, but there are no adequate and well-controlled studies in pregnant women. Animal reproduction studies have shown an adverse effect on the fetus, but adequate and well-controlled studies in pregnant women have failed to demonstrate a risk to the fetus in any trimester.

Examples - Amoxicillin and Ondansetron

Category C

Animal reproduction studies have shown an adverse effect on the fetus, and there are no adequate and well-controlled studies in humans, but potential benefits may warrant use of the drug in pregnant women despite potential risks.

Examples - Metoprolol and fluconazole

Category D

There is positive evidence of human fetal risk based on adverse reaction data from investigational or marketing experience or studies in humans, but potential benefits may warrant the use of the drug in pregnant women despite potential risks.

Examples - ACE inhibitors, Lithium and Phenytoin

Category X

Studies in animals or humans have demonstrated fetal abnormalities, and there is positive evidence of human fetal risk based on adverse reaction data from investigational or marketing experience.

Risks involved inthe use of the drug in pregnant women clearly outweigh the potential benefit.s

Examples - Methotrexate, Warfarin and Statins

 

Schedule

Description

Schedule C

Biological and Special Products: Includes sera, vaccines, toxins, antitoxins, insulin, etc.

Schedule D

Drugs: Extends to diagnostic kits and reagents, including various biotechnological products.

Schedule E

Substances: These include toxic substances such as poisonous plants and their preparations.

Schedule F

Vaccines and Sera: Specifies standards for blood products and diagnostic antigens.

Schedule G

Prescription Drugs: Drugs that should be taken under medical supervision only and must carry a warning.

Schedule H

Prescription Only Drugs: Sale is restricted to prescriptions from a registered medical practitioner.

Schedule J

Diseases: List of diseases for which medicines cannot be claimed to cure or treat, such as cancer, AIDS, etc.

Schedule O

Disinfectants and Insecticides

Schedule R

Standards for Cosmetics: Specifies standards for soaps, shampoos, creams, etc.

Schedule W

Drugs marketed under generic names.

Schedule X

Narcotic and Psychotropic Substances

Schedule Y

Requirement and guidelines for import/manufacture or Clinical trials in India

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of cyclosporine?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Inhibition of calcineurin

Cyclosporine

MOA

  • Binds to cyclophilin, a protein that is expressed in T-cells, and this complex then binds to and inhibits calcineurin
  • It results in a reduced transcription of cytokine genes for IL-2, TNF-alpha, IL-3, IL-4, CD40L and Granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factors and interferon-gamma
  • Ultimately, this results in a reduction in T-cell proliferation - Immunosuppression and immunomodulation

Uses

  • Post-solid organ transplantation - to avoid organ rejection
  • Rheumatoid arthritis, which has not responded to methotrexate
  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
  • Steroid resistant Foca segental glomerulosclerosis
  • Psoriasis

Adverse effect

  • Reduced GFR
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Dyslipidemia
  • Gynecomastia
  • Hypertrichosis
  • Neurotoxicity - convulsion

MOA

  • Activated hyperpolarising potassium current, which enhances GABA-A receptor
  • Limits the activation of AMPA-kainate subtype of glutamate receptors.
  • Modulationof the activity of GABA and glutamate

Uses

  • Focal and primary generalized epilepsy
  • Refractory focal epilepsy
  • Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS)
  • Prophylaxis of migraine
  • Obesity

Pharmacokinetics

  • 20% is bound to plasma proteins
  • Excreted in urine unchanged with a t1/2 of 24 hours
  • Enzyme activation occurs

Adverse effects

  • Somnolence, weight loss, fatigue, nervousness
  • Renal calculi formation
  • Cognitive impairment

questions.text: Inhaled Nitric oxide is approved for the treatment of?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Pulmonary hypertension

Nitric Oxide

Inhaled nitric oxide is a gas that is used to treat pulmonary hypertension because it acts as a potent vasodilator, meaning it relaxes the smooth muscle in the walls of the pulmonary arteries and improves blood flow.

MOA

Activation of guanylate cyclase, which converts guanosine triphosphate (GTP) to cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP)

cGMP causes relaxation of the smooth muscle cells in the pulmonary arteries, leading to vasodilation of the vessels

Uses

Therapeutic indication

  • Pulmonary arterial hypertension
  • Rescue therapy for severely hypoxemic patients

 

Diagnostic indication

  • To evaluate pulmonary reactivity during cardiac catheterisation.
  • To determine diffusion capacity across the alveolar-capillary unit.

Adverse effects

  • Headache, nausea and vomiting
  • Methemoglobinemia
  • It may worsen left ventricular performance in those with impaired ventricular function.

Drugs for Pulmonary artery hypertension

Mechanism of action

Drugs

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for a patient who frequently experiences a sense of contamination in their hands and compulsively washes them, leading to distress and impaired performance?
questions.explanation:
Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)

Obsessions

Compulsions
  • Intrusive and unwanted repetitive thoughts, urges, or impulses.
  • Most common: Contamination
  • Repetitive actions or thoughts carried out in a strict, regulation-bound manner or reaction to obsessions
  • Performed to relieve anxiety or fear.
  • Most common: Checking

Clinical Presentation of OCD:

  • Contamination and Cleansing (Most Common):
    • Obsession with contamination followed by compulsive washing and avoidance of presumed contaminants.
  • Pathological Doubt and Checking (Second Most Common):
    • Persistent doubt leading to repeated checking.
  • Intrusive or Forbidden Thoughts (Third Most Common):
    • ​​​​​​​Obsessive thoughts of aggressive or sexual acts, typically without accompanying compulsions.
  • Symmetry and Ordering (Fourth Most Common):
    • ​​​​​​​Preoccupation with symmetry or precision, resulting in compulsions like slow and deliberate actions.
  • Other Symptoms:
    • ​​​​​​​Includes religious obsessions and compulsive hoarding.

Management of OCD:

  • Pharmacotherapy:
    • First-line Treatment: SSRIs and Clomipramine, continued for 1–2 years.
    • Augmentation Options:
      • Antipsychotics: Risperidone, Aripiprazole.
      • Others: Memantine, Riluzole, Ketamine, Lamotrigine, N-acetylcysteine (NAC).
  • Psychotherapy:
    • Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP): Patients face feared situations while refraining from compulsive responses.
    • Additional Therapies: Desensitization, thought-stopping, flooding, aversive conditioning, psychodynamic psychotherapy, and family therapy.
    • Severe Symptoms or Comorbid Depression: Begin with pharmacotherapy.
  • Somatic Therapies:
    • Anterior cingulotomy or capsulotomy.
    • Deep brain stimulation with electrode implantation.

questions.text: What is a true statement about nicotine substitution therapy?

options.label: B
options.text: Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death

options.label: C
options.text: There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption

options.label: D
options.text: Nicotine chewing gum is better for constant use as it gives 25% higher blood level than lozenges

questions.correct_answer: C. There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption
questions.explanation:
Treatment of Nicotine addiction

Therapy

Description

Nicotine gum
  • Smokers can use 1-2 gums per hour and a maximum of 24 gums per day.
  • It releases nicotine by chewing and buccal absorption.
  • Beverages like coffee, tea, soda, and juice should not be used during gum use because they decrease absorption.
  • Poor compliance is a drawback.

Nicotine lozenges
  • Users must suck the lozenges until it is completely dissolved and must not swallow it.
  • Useful for people who smoke immediately after awakening.
  • It provides the highest level of nicotine compared to other nicotine replacement therapies.

﻿﻿Nicotine patches
  • Attached to the skin
  • Continuous delivery of nicotine and is available as 16 or 24-hour tapering preparations.
  • It has good compliance.

﻿﻿Nicotine nasal spray
  • Provides nicotine concentration in the blood similar to
    Smoking.
  • Major adverse effects are rhinitis, watering eyes, and coughing

﻿﻿Nicotine inhaler
  • Nicotine absorption occurs in the upper throat, not the lungs

Non-nicotine medications
  • ﻿﻿Bupropion (an antidepressant): It has dopaminergic and adrenergic actions.
  • ﻿﻿Varenicline is a partial agonist of alpha-4 beta-2 nicotinic receptors.
    • It blocks nicotine from binding to the receptor and decreases the rewarding aspects of cigarette smoking.
    • It also stimulates the receptor and reduces withdrawal and cravings.
    • Comes with a black box warning of serious neuropsychiatric events like agitation, mood changes, and suicidal thoughts.
  • ﻿﻿Nortriptyline (Second-line drug)
  • ﻿﻿Clonidine: It decreases the sympathetic activity from locus ceruleus and is useful in controlling withdrawal symptoms.

Nicotine replacement therapy

Non-nicotine medications
  • Nicotine gum
  • Nicotine lozenges
  • Nicotine patches
  • Nicotine nasal spray
  • Nicotine inhaler
  • Bupropion
  • ﻿﻿Varenicline
  • ﻿﻿Nortriptyline
  • ﻿﻿Clonidine

Provisions

Description

Advance directive

It is a legal document that allows individuals to specify their preferences regarding:

  • Medical or mental health treatment in the future
  • Particularly if they become incapable of making decisions at that time.
  • Empower individuals to express their wishes regarding treatment, including choosing a caretaker or outlining their desired course of action.
 

Advance directives are meant to ensure that an individual's autonomy and preferences are respected and followed in the event of incapacity.

Treatment directive

(Option A)

It is a legal document that outlines a person's preferences for medical treatment if they cannot make decisions for themselves.

Mental will

(Option B)

It is not a commonly used term or provision in the context of mental health legislation; however, it is an advance directive for mental health care or the exercise of autonomy in mental health treatment decisions.

Future directive

(Option C)

It is a general term that could refer to various legal documents or provisions related to specifying preferences or instructions for future medical or mental health treatment.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has a history of urinating in public without having any remorse for it. She also has difficulty in getting motivated and has mild memory deficits. Which of the following lobes may be affected?
questions.explanation:
A damaged part of the brain

Description

Frontal lobe

  • It plays a crucial role in executive functions, which include decision-making, motivation, impulse control, emotional regulation, and social behaviour.
  • Dysfunction or lesions in the frontal lobe can lead to changes in behaviour, impulsivity, disinhibition, impaired judgment, and difficulties in motivation.

Parietal lobe
  • It is primarily involved in processing sensory information and spatial awareness.
  • It plays a role in integrating sensory input, perception of touch, spatial orientation, and body awareness.

Occipital lobe
  • It is primarily responsible for processing visual information.
  • It is involved in visual perception, object recognition, and visual memory.

Temporal lobe
  • It involves various functions: memory, language processing, auditory perception, and emotional regulation.

Increases uveoscleral outflow

Sandy eyes, orbital fat atrophy, anterior uveitis, cystoid macular edema, heterochromia iridis, hypertrichosis

Reduces aqueous secretion

Adverse effects:

Allergic blepharoconjunctivitis, dry eyes, corneal hypoesthesia

Alpha-2 Agonists:

Brimonidine (long-term use), Apraclonidine (IOP spikes)

Mechanism:

Reduces aqueous production, increases uveoscleral outflow

Adverse effects:

Lid retraction, respiratory depression (Brimonidine), allergic blepharoconjunctivitis

Contraindications:

Children <2 years

Additional:

Miotics:

Pilocarpine, Physostigmine, Echothiophate

Mechanism:

Stimulates M3 receptors, increasing trabecular outflow

Adverse effects:

Brow pain, miosis, cataract (Echothiophate), retinal tears

Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors: (Option C)

Acetazolamide (systemic), Brinzolamide, Dorzolamide (topical)

Mechanism:

Inhibits aqueous secretion

Ciliary edema, secondary angle-closure glaucoma

Mannitol (IV), Glycerol (oral)

Mechanism:

Lowers IOP by creating an osmotic gradient

questions.text: A 5-year-old child who presented with proptosis of one of the eyes was found to have a desmin-positive tumour. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS)

Origin

A malignant tumour arising from skeletal muscle progenitors

Types

  • Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.
  • Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma.
  • Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma.
  • Spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma

Clinical features
  • It is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in children and adolescents.
  • It commonly presents in the extremities.
  • Pediatric rhabdomyosarcomas mostly arise in the sinuses, head and neck, and genitourinary tract.

IHC Positive Markers
  • Desmin
  • Myogenin
  • MyoD1
  • Muscle-specific actin

Gross appearance
  • The tumours are often large, soft, and infiltrative, with areas of necrosis and haemorrhage.

Microscopy

  • Small, round to spindle-shaped cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scant cytoplasm, sometimes with a myxoid stroma, are also seen.

Tumour

Translocation

Ewing's Sarcoma
  • t(11;22)
  • Fusion of the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 with the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11 leads to oncogenesis.

Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • t(1;13)

Liposarcoma
  • t(12;16)

Synovial Sarcoma
  • t(x;18)
  • The fusion of the SS18 gene on chromosome 18 with the SSX gene on the X-chromosome promotes oncogenic transformation.

questions.text: What is the primary mode of dissemination of retinoblastoma?
questions.explanation:
ICRB Stage

Features

Treatment

A
  • Small intraretinal tumors (<3mm)
  • Located >3 mm from the foveola and >1.5 mm from the optic disc

 
  • Laser photocoagulation: Posterior to equator
  • Cryotherapy: Anterior to equator
  • Thermotherapy
  • Chemoreduction (Etoposide, Vincristine and Carboplatin)

B
  • Large tumors >3 mm in dimension
  • Any size tumors located <3 mm from fovea, and <1.5 mm from the optic disc margin
  • Chemoreduction + focal consolidation
  • Plaque radiotherapy

C
  • Subretinal seeds ≤ 3 mm from tumor
  • Vitreous seeds ≤ 3 mm from tumor
  • Both subretinal and vitreous seeds ≤ 3 mm from tumor
  • Chemoreduction + focal consolidation
  • Possible intravitreal chemotherapy for vitreous seeding

D
  • Subretinal seeds > 3 mm from tumor
  • Vitreous seeds > 3 mm from tumor
  • Both subretinal and vitreous seeds > 3 mm from retinoblastoma
  • Chemoreduction + possible intravitreal chemotherapy
  • External beam radiotherapy in some cases
  • Enucleation if poor response to other treatments

E

Extensive retinoblastoma occupying > 50% of the globe with or without:

  • Neovascular glaucoma
  • Hemorrhage
  • Extension of tumor to optic nerve or anterior chamber
  • Enucleation
  • Possible adjuvant chemotherapy if high-risk features

questions.explanation:
Investigations

  • Micro-immunofluorescence (micro-IF): Using pooled antigens; For routine diagnostic purposes
  • Culture of C. trachomatis: In irradiated McCoy cells; Expensive
  • Monoclonal antibody direct tests: IgA-IPA light microscopy tests are the best combination for diagnosis

Management (SAFE strategy)

 

SAFE is a WHO-recommended combination of interventions to treat trachoma and prevent it from leading to blindness

  • Surgery for cicatricial entropion and trichiasis (Tertiary prevention)
  • Antibiotics to eliminate the organism (Secondary prevention)
  • Facial cleanliness to avoid infection (Primary prevention)
  • Environmental improvement with better hygiene and sanitation (Primordial prevention)

Surgery (Tertiary prevention) (Option B)

Epilation/ Bilamellar tarsal rotation

Antibiotics (Secondary prevention) (Option A)
  • For areas with 10% or more prevalence of active trachoma (TF in children 1-9 yrs): Azithromycin single oral dose 20 mg/kg to all community members
  • 5% to 10% prevalence: Antibiotic therapy targeted in the family and close contact only
  • Less than 5% prevalence: Only patients are treated

Facial cleanliness (Primary prevention) (Option D)

Frequent face wash with clean water, Avoid common towels, handkerchiefs, Surma rods, etc

Environmental improvement (Primordial prevention) (Option C)

Water latrines and good water supply to reduce flies, Sprays to control flies, Health education

questions.text: Which of the following can be prevented by transfusing irradiated RBCs?
questions.explanation:
Steps for Production of Red Blood Cell Concentrates (RBCC) from Whole Blood

1

Whole Blood Collection

  • Blood is drawn into sterile bags with anticoagulants to prevent clotting. Each unit contains 450-500 mL. (First 20-30 ml is discarded due to skin flora contamination)

2

Slow Speed Centrifugation (Soft Spin)

  • Separates Red Blood Cell Concentrate (RBCC) at the bottom and Platelet-Rich Plasma (PRP) at the top, with the buffy coat (white blood cells) in between.

3

RBCC Processing and Additive Solutions

  • After removing plasma and buffy coat, additive solutions like SAGM (Saline, Adenine, Glucose, Mannitol) or CPD are added to preserve cell viability and extend shelf life.

4

Leukoreduction/ Deleucocytation

Achieved by filtering RBCC to remove >99.9% of white blood cells.

Purpose:

  • Nonhemolytic Febrile Transfusion Reactions (NHFTRs). (Option D ruled out)
  • Alloimmunization and platelet transfusion refractoriness. (Option B ruled out)
  • Transfusion-transmitted infections, such as cytomegalovirus (CMV).
  • Immunomodulation risks from transfusions (Option C ruled out)

 

Post-reduction leukocyte content: <1–5 x 10⁶ leukocytes/unit.

5

Irradiation (Optional)

  • RBCC is irradiated with X-rays or gamma rays (25–35 Gy).
  • Purpose: Prevents graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) by inactivating donor lymphocytes.(Option A)
  • Use: RBCC must be transfused within 24 hours post-irradiation.

6

Plasma Reduction (Optional)

  • Plasma proteins are removed to prevent allergic or anaphylactic reactions.

Purpose: Useful for patients with a history of allergic transfusion reactions, reducing post-transfusion anaphylaxis risk.

7

Cryopreservation (Optional)

  • RBCC is cryopreserved at -80°C, mainly for rare blood types.

Purpose: Extends shelf life up to 30 years, increasing availability of rare blood groups.

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis?
questions.explanation:
Myocarditis

It is a diverse group of pathologic entities in which infectious microorganisms and/or a primary inflammatory process cause myocardial injury.

Pathogenesis

Infections:

  • Viruses (e.g., Coxsackievirus, Echovirus, Influenza, HIV, Cytomegalovirus)
  • Chlamydiae (e.g., Chlamydophila psittaci)
  • Rickettsiae (e.g., Rickettsia typhi, Typhus fever)
  • Bacteria (e.g., Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Neisseria meningococcus, Borrelia)
  • Fungi (e.g., Candida) Protozoa (e.g., Trypanosoma cruzi [Chagas disease], toxoplasmosis) Helminths (e.g., Trichinosis)

 

Immune-Mediated Reactions

  • Postviral
  • Poststreptococcal (Rheumatic fever)
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Drug hypersensitivity (e.g., methyldopa, sulfonamides)
  • Transplant rejection
  • Immune checkpoint inhibitor therapies

 

Unknown

  • Sarcoidosis
  • Giant cell myocarditis

Clinical features
  • It can be asymptomatic (recovery without sequelae)
  • Heart failure
  • Arrhythmias
  • Sudden death
  • Symptoms include fatigue, dyspnea, palpitations, precordial discomfort, and fever.

Type of Carditis

Features

Pericarditis
  • Inflammation of the pericardium with infiltration of inflammatory cells (e.g., lymphocytes) and fibrinous exudate.
  • It can lead to fibrinous or serofibrinous pericarditis with friction rub.
  • Chronicity may cause fibrous adhesions, leading to constrictive pericarditis and impaired cardiac filling.

Myocarditis
  • Inflammation of the myocardium with infiltration of inflammatory cells (e.g., lymphocytes, macrophages).
  • It may show myocyte necrosis, interstitial oedema, and inflammatory infiltrates.
  • Severe cases can progress to myocardial fibrosis, dilated cardiomyopathy, and heart failure.

Endocarditis
  • Inflammation of the endocardium, especially affecting heart valves.
  • Features bacterial vegetations of fibrin, platelets, and microbial colonies, which can erode tissues, causing valvular destruction, chordae tendineae rupture, or myocardial abscess.
  • Chronic endocarditis leads to valve thickening, incompetence, or stenosis.

questions.text: Identify the site of the lesion.
questions.explanation:
Components of Visual Pathway

Retina
  • First-order Neurons: Bipolar cells in the inner nuclear layer of the retina.
  • Second-order Neurons: Ganglion cells in the retina; their axons form the optic nerve.

Optic Nerve
  • Carries visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm.
  • Temporal and Nasal fibres of the same eye.

Optic Chiasma
  • Partial decussation occurs
  • Nasal fibres cross to the opposite side, while temporal fibres remain ipsilateral.

Optic Tract
  • Carries visual information from the optic chiasma to the Lateral Geniculate body (LGB).
  • Temporal fibres of the same eye and Nasal fibres of the opposite eye.

Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB)
  • Third Order Neurons: Relay visual information to the visual cortex.

Optic Radiations
  • Meyer's Loop: Carries information from lower retinal quadrants to the inferior part of the visual cortex.
  • Baum’s Loop (Dorsal): Carries information from upper retinal quadrants to the superior part of the visual cortex.

Occipital Cortex
  • The primary visual cortex (V1), corresponding to Brodmann area 17, is situated on the medial side of the occipital lobe, particularly along the borders of the calcarine fissure.

Visual Pathway Lesions and Defects

Site of Lesion

Fibers Affected

Field Defect

Optic Nerve

Ipsilateral Temporal + Nasal Fibers

Anopia

Optic Chiasma

Bilateral Nasal Fibers

Bitemporal Hemianopia

(Heteronymous Hemianopia) (Option D)

Optic Tract/ Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB)/ Optic Radiation

Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers

Homonymous Hemianopia (Option C)

Visual Cortex without the involvement of tip

(Posterior Cerebral Artery)

Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers except macular representation

Homonymous Hemianopia with Macular Sparing (Option A)

Tip of Visual Cortex

Macular Homonymous Hemianopia

Feature

Physiological Jaundice

Pathological Jaundice

Timing

Appears 24-72 hours after birth; peaks at 3-5 days; resolves by 1-2 weeks

Appears within 24 hours of birth or persists beyond the expected timeframe

Cause

Elevated unconjugated bilirubin due to increased production and immature liver function

Blood group incompatibility, infections, metabolic disorders, genetic conditions

Clinical Presentation

Yellowing of skin and sclera, starting from the face, progressing to the trunk and extremities

Similar to physiological jaundice, but potentially more severe and may include other symptoms

Treatment

Usually self-resolving; observation and reassurance; phototherapy may be used if needed (Option D)

Depends on the underlying cause; may include phototherapy, exchange transfusion, or specific treatments

Treatment

Usually self-resolving; observation and reassurance; phototherapy may be used if needed

questions.text: A patient with lytic lesions on the skull is suspected of a diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Which of the following is a characteristic finding of electron microscopy?

A 6-year-old boy came with bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the probable diagnosis, cell, and virus associated with the image given below? RS cell: Reed Stemberg cell HIV: Human immunodeficiency virus CMV: Cytomegalovirus EBV: Epstein–Barr virus
questions.correct_answer: C. Hodgkin’s lymphoma, RS cell, EBV
questions.explanation:
Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Etiology
  • M ore common in whites & Males.
  • Bimodal age distribution with peaks in the 20s and 80s.
  • It is not a part of AIDS-defining lymphoma.
  • Risk Factors:
    •  HIV infection is a major risk factor.
    • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). (Option C)

Reed-Sternberg (HRS) Cells

(Option C)
  • HRS cells are derived from the germinal centre or post-germinal centre B cells (mature B cells in peripheral lymph nodes).
  • Diagnostic of HL.
  • Large, with abundant cytoplasm, bilobed or multinucleated.
  • Typically positive for PAX-5, CD15, and CD30.

NF-κB Activation
  • Common in cHL, promoting RS cell growth and survival.
  • EBV+ Tumors: Express latent membrane protein-1 (LMP-1), which activates NF-κB.
  • EBV− Tumors: NF-κB activation may result from loss-of-function mutations in IκB or loss-of-function mutation of TNF-α–induced protein 3, both of which normally inhibit NF-κB.
  • NF-κB activation may rescue "crippled" B cells that can't express Ig, preventing apoptosis and enabling further mutations that form RS cells.

Immune Evasion
  • Genetic abnormalities at the PD-L1 locus on chromosome 9p24.1 lead to PD-L1 overexpression, which helps the tumour evade immune detection.

An 18-month-old baby was brought to the hospital with complaints of poor feeding and abnormal twitching of his lower limbs. On examination, he has fever with fontanelle bulging, and the child was lethargic. The most probable cause is:
questions.explanation:
In India

Overall

Neonates

Gram-negative organisms

(E.Coli > Acinetobacter > Klebsiella)

Group B streptococci

Infants and older children

Streptococcus Pneumoniae >

Neisseria Meningitidis > Haemophilus influenzae.

Streptococcus pneumoniae

Category

Clinical Manifestations

Nonspecific Findings
  • Fever, anorexia, poor feeding
  • Headache, upper respiratory symptoms
  • Myalgias, arthralgias
  • Tachycardia, hypotension
  • Cutaneous signs: Petechiae, purpura, or erythematous macular rash

Meningeal Irritation
  • Nuchal rigidity
  • Back pain
  • Kernig sign: Pain with extension of the leg after hip flexion
  • Brudzinski sign: Involuntary flexion of the knees and hips upon neck flexion

Increased Intracranial Pressure (ICP) Signs
  • Headache, emesis
  • Bulging fontanel or diastasis of sutures
  • Cranial nerve involvement: anisocoria, ptosis, abducens nerve paralysis
  • Hypertension with bradycardia, apnea, or hyperventilation
  • Decorticate or decerebrate posturing, stupor, coma, or herniation signs
  • Papilledema

Focal Neurologic Signs
  • Seizures
  • Altered mental status
  • Photophobia
  • Tâche cérébrale: Raised red streak appearing 30-60 seconds after stroking the skin with a blunt object
